summary.long: Exodus is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: These are the names of the Israelis who entered Egypt with Jacob, each one having come with his family:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Reuben, Simeon, Levi, Judah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Issacar, Zebulun, Benjamin,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Dan, Naphtali, Gad, and Asher.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All those who descended from Jacob totaled 75 persons. Now Joseph was already in Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joseph, all his brothers, and that entire generation died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Israelis were fruitful and increased abundantly. They multiplied in numbers and became very, very strong. As a result, the land was filled with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eventually a new king who was unacquainted with Joseph came to power in Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He told his people, “Look, the Israeli people are more numerous and more powerful than we are.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Come on, let’s be careful how we treat them, so that when they grow numerous, if a war breaks out they won’t join our enemies, fight against us, and leave our land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Egyptians placed supervisors over them, oppressing them with heavy burdens. The Israelis built the supply cities of Pithom and Rameses for Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the more the Egyptians afflicted the Israelis, the more they multiplied and flourished, so that the Egyptians became terrified of the Israelis.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Egyptians ruthlessly forced the Israelis to serve them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: making their lives bitter through hard labor with mortar, bricks, and all kinds of outdoor labor. They ruthlessly imposed all this work on them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later, the king of Egypt spoke to the Hebrew midwives, one of whom was named Shiphrah and the other Puah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When you help the Hebrew women give birth,” he said, “watch them as they deliver. If it’s a son, kill him; but if it’s a daughter, let her live.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the midwives feared God and didn’t do what the king of Egypt told them. Instead, they let the boys live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the king of Egypt called for the midwives, he asked them, “Why have you done this and allowed the boys to live?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Hebrew women aren’t like Egyptian women,” the midwives replied to Pharaoh. “They’re so healthy that they give birth before the midwives arrive to help them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God was pleased with the midwives, and the people multiplied and became very strong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because the midwives feared God, he provided families for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, Pharaoh continued commanding all of his people, “You’re to throw every Hebrew son who is born into the Nile River, but you’re to allow every Hebrew daughter to live.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A man of the family of Levi married the daughter of a descendant of Levi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later, the woman became pregnant and gave birth to a son. She saw that he was a beautiful child, and hid him for three months.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when she was no longer able to hide him, she took a papyrus container, coated it with asphalt and pitch, placed the child in it, and put it among the reeds along the bank of the Nile.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then his sister positioned herself some distance away in order to find out what would happen to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh’s daughter came down to the Nile River to bathe while her maids walked along the river bank. She saw the container among the reeds and sent a servant girl to get it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When she opened it and saw the child, the little boy suddenly began crying. Filled with compassion for him, she exclaimed, “This is one of the Hebrew children!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then his sister asked Pharaoh’s daughter, “Shall I go and call one of the nursing Hebrew women so she can nurse the child for you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh’s daughter told her, “Go,” so the young girl went and called the child’s mother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh’s daughter instructed her, “Take this child and nurse him for me, and I’ll pay you a salary.” So the woman took the child and nursed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the child had grown older, she brought him to Pharaoh’s daughter, and he became her son. She named him Moses, because she said, “I drew him out of the water.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Years later, after Moses had grown up, he went out to his own people, and took notice of their heavy burdens. He saw an Egyptian beating up a Hebrew, one of his own people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Looking around and seeing no one else, he killed the Egyptian and hid him in the sand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Going out the next day, Moses noticed two Hebrew men fighting right in front of him. He told the one who was at fault, “Why did you strike your companion?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The man replied, “Who appointed you to be an official judge over us? Are you planning to kill me like you killed the Egyptian?”
Then Moses became terrified and told himself, “Certainly this event has become known!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Pharaoh heard about this matter, he tried to kill Moses. So Moses fled from Pharaoh, settled in the land of Midian, and sat down by a well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, the seven daughters of a certain Midianite priest would come to draw water in order to fill water troughs for their father’s sheep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some shepherds came to drive them away, but Moses got up, came to their rescue, and watered their sheep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they returned to their father Reuel, he asked, “Why have you returned so quickly today?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “An Egyptian rescued us from the shepherds,” they replied, “and he even drew water for us and watered the sheep!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then where is he?” He asked his daughters. “Why did you leave the man behind? Go invite him to have something to eat.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses agreed to stay with the man, and he gave his daughter Zipporah to Moses in marriage.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later she gave birth to a son, and Moses named him Gershom, because he used to say, “I became an alien in a foreign land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Egypt eventually died, and the Israelis groaned because of the bondage. They cried out, and their cry for deliverance from slavery ascended to God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God heard their groaning and remembered his covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God watched the Israelis and took notice of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, Moses continued tending the sheep that belonged to his father-in-law Jethro, the priest of Midian. He led the sheep to the western desert and came to Horeb, God’s mountain, where
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the angel of the Lord appeared to him in flaming fire from the center of a bush. As Moses continued to watch, amazingly the bush kept on burning, but was not consumed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses told himself, “I’ll go over and see this remarkable sight. Why isn’t the bush burning up?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the Lord saw that he had gone over to look, God called to him from the center of the bush, “Moses! Moses!”
He said, “Here I am.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: “Do not come any closer,” God said. “Remove your sandals from your feet, because the place where you are standing is holy ground.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: Then he said, “I am the God of your ancestors, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob.” At this, Moses hid his face, because he was afraid to look at God.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: The Lord said, “I have certainly seen the affliction of my people who are in Egypt, and I have heard their cry caused by their slave masters. I really do understand their pain,
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: so I have come down to deliver them from their domination by the Egyptians and to bring them out of that land to a good and spacious land, a land flowing with milk and honey, to the territory of the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Amorites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: Now, listen carefully! The cry of the Israelis has come to my attention about how severely the Egyptians have been oppressing them.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: So go! I am sending you to Pharaoh. Bring my people the Israelis out of Egypt.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: But Moses told God, “Who am I? How can I go to Pharaoh and bring the Israelis out of Egypt?”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: Then God said, “I certainly will be with you. And this will be the sign for you that it is I who sent you: When you have brought the people out of Egypt, all of you will serve God on this mountain.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: Moses told God, “Look! When I go to the Israelis and tell them, ‘The God of your ancestors sent me to you,’ they’ll say to me, ‘What is his name?’ What should I say to them?”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: God replied to Moses, “I AM WHO I AM,” and then said, “Tell the Israelis: ‘I AM sent me to you.’”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: God also told Moses, “Tell the Israelis, ‘The Lord, the God of your ancestors, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob sent me to you.’ This is my name forever, and this is how I am to be remembered from generation to generation.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: “Go and gather the elders of Israel. Tell them, ‘The Lord God of your ancestors, appeared to me—the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob—and he said, “I have paid close attention to you and to what has been done to you in Egypt.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: I have said that I will bring you out of the affliction of Egypt to the land of the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Amorites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites—to a land flowing with milk and honey.”’
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: “The elders of Israel will listen to you, and then you and they are to go to the king of Egypt and say to him, ‘The Lord God of the Hebrews has met with us. Now, let us take a three-day journey into the desert to sacrifice to the Lord our God.’
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: I know that the king of Egypt won’t allow you to go unless compelled to do so by force,
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: so I will stretch out my hand and strike Egypt with all my wonders that I will do there. After that he will release you.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: I will grant this people public favor with the Egyptians, and as a result, when you leave you won’t go empty-handed.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: Each woman is to ask her neighbor or any foreign woman in her house for articles of gold and for clothing, and use them to clothe your sons and daughters. You will plunder the Egyptians.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: Then Moses answered, “Look, they won’t believe me and they won’t listen to me. Instead, they’ll say, ‘The Lord didn’t appear to you.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“What’s that in your hand?” the Lord asked him.
Moses answered, “A staff.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then God said, “Throw it to the ground.” He threw it to the ground and it became a snake. Moses ran away from it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then God told Moses, “Reach out and grab its tail.” So he reached out, grabbed it, and it became a staff in his hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said, “I’ve done this so that they may believe that the Lord God of their ancestors—the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob—has appeared to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Again the Lord told him, “Put your hand into your bosom.” He put his hand into his bosom and as soon as he brought it out it was leprous, like snow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then God said, “Put your hand back into your bosom.” He returned it to his bosom and as soon as he brought it out, it was restored like the rest of his skin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then if they don’t believe you and respond to the first sign, they may respond to the second sign.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if they don’t believe even these two signs, and won’t listen to you, then take some water out of the Nile River and pour it on the dry ground. The water you took from the Nile River will turn into blood on the dry ground.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses told the Lord, “Please, Lord, I’m not eloquent. I never was in the past nor am I now since you spoke to your servant. In fact, I talk too slowly and I have a speech impediment.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then God asked him, “Who gives a person a mouth? Who makes him unable to speak, or deaf, or able to see, or blind, or lame? Is it not I, the Lord?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, go! I myself will help you with your speech, and I’ll teach you what you are to say.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said, “Please, Lord, send somebody else.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord was angry with Moses and said, “There’s your brother Aaron, a descendant of Levi, isn’t there? I know that he certainly is eloquent. Right now he’s coming to meet you and he will be pleased to see you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You’re to speak to him and tell him what to say. I’ll help both you and him with your speech, and I’ll teach both of you what you are to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He is to speak to the people for you as your spokesman and you are to act in the role of God for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now pick up that staff with your hand. You’ll use it to perform the signs.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Moses left and returned to his father-in-law Jethro. Moses told him, “Please let me go and return to my own people in Egypt so I can see whether they’re still alive.”
Jethro told Moses, “Go in peace.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord told Moses in Midian, “Go back to Egypt, because all the men who wanted to kill you are dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses took his wife and sons, put them on donkeys, and headed back to the land of Egypt. Moses took the staff of God in his hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord told Moses, “When you set out to return to Egypt, keep in mind all the wonders that I’ve put in your power, so that you may do them before Pharaoh. But I’ll harden his heart so that he won’t let the people go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are to say to Pharaoh, ‘This is what the Lord says: “Israel is my firstborn son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I say to you, ‘Let my son go so he may serve me. If you refuse to let him go, then I will kill your firstborn son.’”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But later on, at the lodging place along the way, the Lord met Moses and was about to kill him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zipporah took a flint knife, cut off her son’s foreskin, and touched Moses’ feet with it, saying while doing so, “…because you are a bridegroom of blood to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord withdrew from him, and she said, “…a bridegroom of blood because of circumcision.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord told Aaron, “Go meet Moses in the desert.” So Aaron went, found him at the mountain of God, and embraced him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses told Aaron all of the Lord’s messages that he had sent with Moses, and all of the signs that he commanded him to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later, Moses and Aaron brought together all the elders of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Aaron spoke everything that the Lord had spoken to Moses, and Moses performed the miracles before the very eyes of the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people believed and understood that the Lord had paid attention to the Israelis and had seen their affliction. They bowed their heads and prostrated themselves in worship.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Moses and Aaron arrived, they told Pharaoh, “This is what the Lord God of Israel says: ‘Let my people go so they may make a pilgrimage for me in the desert.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh said, “Who is the Lord that I should listen to him and let Israel go? I don’t know about the Lord, nor will I let Israel go!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they said, “The God of the Hebrews has met with us. Please let us go a three-day journey into the desert to offer sacrifices to the Lord our God so he does not strike us with pestilence or sword.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Egypt replied to them, “Moses and Aaron, why are you keeping the people from their labor? Go back to your work!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh said, “Look, the people in the land are now numerous, and you are stopping them from working.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That day Pharaoh ordered the taskmasters of the people and their officials,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You’re no longer to give the people straw for making bricks, as in the past. They must gather straw for themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you’re to impose the previous quota of bricks that they’re making. You’re not to reduce it! It is because they’re lazy that they’re crying out, ‘Let’s go offer sacrifices to our God.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So increase the work load on the people, and let them do it so they don’t pay attention to deceptive speeches.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the taskmasters of the people and their officials went out and told the people, “This is Pharaoh’s response: ‘I’ll no longer give you any straw.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go get straw for yourselves wherever you can find it, but your work quotas won’t be reduced at all.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the people scattered throughout the entire land of Egypt to collect stubble for straw.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The taskmasters pressured them by saying, “Finish your work—each day’s quota—just as when you were given straw.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israeli supervisors whom Pharaoh’s taskmasters had appointed over them were beaten and told, “Why didn’t you, both yesterday and today, fulfill your quota for making bricks as before?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israeli supervisors came and cried out to Pharaoh, “Why are you doing this to us?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No straw is being given to us, yet they’re saying to us, ‘Make bricks!’ Look, we are being beaten. It’s wrong how you are treating your people!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh said, “You are lazy, lazy! That’s why you’re saying, ‘Let’s go offer sacrifices to the Lord.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, go! Get to work! And straw won’t be given to you, but you are to deliver the same number of bricks!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israeli supervisors realized they were in trouble when he said, “You won’t reduce each day’s quota of bricks!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As they left Pharaoh’s presence, they met Moses and Aaron standing there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The supervisors told them, “May the Lord look on you and judge you! You have made us repulsive to Pharaoh and his servants. You have put a sword in their hands to kill us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses returned to the Lord and asked him, “Lord, why have you caused trouble for this people? Why have you sent me here?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ever since I came to Pharaoh to speak in your name, he has caused trouble for this people, and you have done nothing to deliver your people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord told Moses, “Now you’re about to see what I’ll do to Pharaoh. Indeed, he’ll send them out under compulsion and he’ll drive them out of his land violently.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later, God told Moses, “I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I appeared to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob as God Almighty, and did I not reveal to them my name ‘Lord’?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I also established my covenant with them to give them the land of Canaan, the land where they lived as resident aliens for a time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also, I’ve heard the groaning of the Israelis whom the Egyptians have forced to labor for them, and I’ve remembered my covenant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, tell the Israelis, ‘I am the Lord. I’ll bring you out from under the burdens of the Egyptians, and I’ll deliver you from their bondage. I’ll redeem you with an outstretched arm and with great acts of judgment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll take you for my own people, and I’ll be your God. Then you will know that I am the Lord your God, who brings you out from under the burdens of the Egyptians.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll bring you to the land that I swore to give to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob. I’ll give it to you as a possession. I am the Lord.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses reported this to the Israelis, but they did not listen to Moses due to their irritation and impatience because there was no deliverance and because of the cruel bondage.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord told Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go, speak to Pharaoh, king of Egypt, that he should let the Israelis go out of his land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses said right in front of the Lord, “Look, the Israelis didn’t listen to me, so how will Pharaoh? I’m not a persuasive speaker.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron, issuing orders to them regarding the Israelis for delivery to Pharaoh, king of Egypt; that is, to bring the Israelis out of the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These are the heads of their ancestors’ households: the sons of Reuben, the firstborn of Israel: Hanoch and Pallu; Hezron and Carmi.
These are the families of Reuben, including
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Simeon’s sons Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jachin, Zohar, and Shaul, the Canaanite woman’s son. These are the families of Simeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the names of Levi’s sons according to their genealogies: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari. Levi lived 137 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gershon’s sons were Libni and Shimei, according to their families.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Kohath’s descendants included Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel. Now Kohath lived for 133 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Merari were Mahli and Mushi. These are the families of the descendants of Levi, according to their genealogies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amram married Jochebed, his father’s sister, and she bore him Aaron and Moses. Amram lived for 137 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Izhar were Korah, Nepheg, and Zichri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Uzziel were Mishael, Elzaphan, and Sithri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Aaron married Elisheba daughter of Amminadab, sister of Nahshon. She bore him Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Korah were Assir, Elkanah, and Abiasaph. These were the families of the descendants of Korah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Aaron’s son Eleazar married one of Putiel’s daughters, and she bore him Phineas. These are the heads of the ancestors of the descendants of Levi, according to their families.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the same Aaron and Moses to whom the Lord said, “Bring the Israelis out of the land of Egypt by their tribal divisions.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They were the ones speaking to Pharaoh, king of Egypt, to bring the Israelis out of Egypt; this is that same Moses and Aaron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And it happened when the Lord spoke to Moses in the land of Egypt
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: that the Lord told Moses, “I am the Lord. Tell Pharaoh, king of Egypt, everything that I’m saying to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said in the presence of the Lord, “Look, I’m not a persuasive speaker, so how will Pharaoh listen to me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord told Moses, “Listen! I’ve positioned you as God to Pharaoh, and your brother Aaron will be your prophet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are to speak everything that I’ve commanded you, and then your brother Aaron will speak to Pharaoh, telling him to let the Israelis go out of his land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll harden Pharaoh’s heart and I’ll add more and more of my signs and wonders in the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Pharaoh won’t listen to you, I’ll let loose my power upon Egypt. I’ll bring out my tribal divisions—my people the Israelis—from the land of Egypt with great acts of judgment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Egyptians will know that I am the Lord when I stretch out my hand over Egypt to bring the Israelis out from among them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses and Aaron did what the Lord commanded them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses was 80 years old and Aaron was 83 when they spoke to Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord told Moses and Aaron,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When Pharaoh says to you, ‘Perform a miraculous sign,’ then you are to say to Aaron, ‘Take your staff and throw it in front of Pharaoh.’ It will become a serpent.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses and Aaron went in to Pharaoh and did what the Lord had commanded them. Aaron threw his staff in front of Pharaoh and his officials, and it became a serpent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh also called for the wise men and sorcerers, and they—along with the Egyptian magicians—did the same thing with their secret arts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So each one threw down his staff and it became a serpent, but Aaron’s staff swallowed up their staffs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yet Pharaoh’s heart was stubborn and he did not listen to them, just as the Lord had said would happen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord told Moses, “Pharaoh’s heart is hard. He has refused to let the people go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go to Pharaoh in the morning as he’s going down to the water. Stand on the bank of the Nile River and meet him. Be sure to take with you the staff that was turned into a snake.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then say to him, ‘The Lord God of the Hebrews, has sent me to you. He says, “Let my people go so they may serve me in the desert, but until now you haven’t obeyed.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “‘This is what the Lord says: “This is how you’ll know that I am the Lord: Right now I’m going to strike the water of the Nile River with the staff that’s in my hand, and it will be turned to blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The fish in the Nile River will die and the river will stink. The Egyptians will be unable to drink water from the Nile River.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord also told Moses, “Tell Aaron, ‘Take your staff and stretch out your hand over the waters of Egypt, over their rivers, over their Nile River, over their ponds, and over their reservoirs, and they’ll become blood. There will be blood throughout the land of Egypt, even in their wood and stone containers.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses and Aaron did just what the Lord had commanded. Aaron raised his staff and struck the water in the Nile River in front of Pharaoh and his officials, and all the water in the Nile River turned to blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The fish in the Nile River died and the river stank. The Egyptians were not able to drink water from the Nile River, and blood was throughout the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Egyptian magicians did the same thing with their secret arts. Pharaoh’s heart was stubborn, and he did not listen to them, just as the Lord had said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh turned away, went to his palace, and paid no attention to any of this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the Egyptians dug around the Nile River for water to drink because they could not drink from the water in the Nile River.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Seven days after the Lord had struck the Nile River,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he told Moses, “Go to Pharaoh and tell him, ‘This is what the Lord says: “Let my people go so they may serve me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And if you refuse to let them go, then I’m going to strike all your territory with frogs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Nile will swarm with frogs. They’ll come up and enter your house, your bedroom, your bed, and your servants’ houses. They’ll jump on your people, into your ovens, and into your kneading troughs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The frogs will be all over you and your servants.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord told Moses, “Tell Aaron, ‘Stretch out your hand with your staff over the rivers, over the Nile River, and over the ponds, and bring up frogs over the land of Egypt.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Aaron stretched his hand over the waters of Egypt, and the frogs came up and covered the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the magicians did the same thing with their secret arts, and they brought up frogs on the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh called to Moses and Aaron and said, “Plead with the Lord so that he may remove the frogs from me and my people. I’ll let the people go so they can offer sacrifices to the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses told Pharaoh, “You decide when I should plead for you, your servants, and your people to remove the frogs from you and your household. They’ll remain only in the Nile River.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Pharaoh said, “Tomorrow.”
Moses said, “It will be just as you say, so that you may know that there is no one like the Lord our God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The frogs will leave you, your house, your officials, and your people. They’ll remain only in the Nile River.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses and Aaron left Pharaoh’s presence, and Moses cried out to the Lord about the frogs which he had sent on Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord did just as Moses asked, and the frogs died in the houses, in the courtyards, and in the fields.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They gathered them up into large piles and the land smelled terrible.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when Pharaoh saw that there was relief, he hardened his heart and did not listen to them, just as the Lord had predicted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord told Moses, “Tell Aaron, ‘Stretch out your staff, strike the dust of the ground, and the dust will become gnats throughout the land of Egypt.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They did this. Aaron stretched his hand out with his staff, struck the dust of the land, and gnats came on people and animals—all the dust of the ground became gnats throughout the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The magicians tried to do the same thing with their secret arts, but they were unable to bring out the gnats. The gnats were on the people and the animals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The magicians told Pharaoh, “It is the finger of God!” But Pharaoh’s heart was stubborn and he did not listen to them, just as the Lord had predicted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord told Moses, “Get up early in the morning and stand before Pharaoh as he’s going down to the water. You are to say to him, ‘This is what the Lord says: “Let my people go so they can serve me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you don’t let my people go, I’ll send swarms of insects upon you, your servants, your people, and your households. The houses of Egypt—and even the ground on which they stand—will be filled with swarms of insects.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On that day I’ll treat the land of Goshen where my people live differently so that swarms of insects won’t be there. As a result, you will know that I the Lord am in the midst of the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll make a distinction between my people and your people, and this sign will occur tomorrow.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord did this, and dense swarms of insects came into the house of Pharaoh and into the houses of his servants. The land was ruined throughout Egypt because of the swarms of insects.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh summoned Moses and Aaron and said, “Go, offer sacrifices to your God in the land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “It wouldn’t be right to sacrifice in this way,” Moses replied, “because if we do, we will sacrifice to the Lord our God what is offensive to the Egyptians. If we offer sacrifices that are offensive to the Egyptians in front of them, they’ll stone us, won’t they?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We must go a three-day journey into the desert, and we’ll offer sacrifices to the Lord our God just as he has told us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh said, “I’ll let you go so you can offer sacrifices to the Lord your God in the desert. But you must not go very far away. Pray for me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said, “Right now I’m going to leave you, and I’ll pray to the Lord that the swarms of insects may depart from Pharaoh, from his officials, and from his people tomorrow. But Pharaoh, don’t continue lying by not letting the people go to offer sacrifices to the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses left Pharaoh’s presence and prayed to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord did what Moses asked, and the swarms of insects departed from Pharaoh, his officials, and his people. Not one remained.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But this time also Pharaoh hardened his heart, and he did not let the people go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord told Moses, “Go to Pharaoh and say to him, ‘This is what the Lord God of the Hebrews says: “Let my people go so they may serve me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you refuse to let them go and continue to hold them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then the hand of the Lord will come with a very severe plague on your livestock in the fields, on horses, on donkeys, on camels, on cattle, and on sheep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord will distinguish between the livestock of Israel and the livestock of the Egyptians, so that nothing that belongs to the Israelis will die.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord set the time: “Tomorrow the Lord will do this thing in the land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord did this thing the next day, and all the livestock of the Egyptians died. But not one of the livestock died that belonged to the Israelis.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh inquired and discovered that not a single one of the livestock of Israel had died, but Pharaoh’s heart was stubborn and he would not let the people go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord told Moses and Aaron, “Take handfuls of soot from a kiln, and let Moses throw it into the air in front of Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The soot will become dust over the entire land of Egypt, and it will become boils erupting into sores on people and animals throughout the land of Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they took soot from the kiln and stood before Pharaoh. Then Moses threw it into the air, and it became boils producing running sores on people and animals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The magicians were not able to stand before Moses because of the boils, because the boils were on the magicians and on all the Egyptians.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord made Pharaoh’s heart stubborn so that he would not listen to them, just as the Lord had told Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord told Moses, “Get up early in the morning, present yourself to Pharaoh, and say to him, ‘This is what the Lord God of the Hebrews says: “Let my people go so they may serve me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Indeed, this time I’m sending all my plagues against you, your officials, and your people, so you may know that there is no one like me in all the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Indeed, by now I could have sent forth my hand and struck you and your people with a plague, and you would have been destroyed from the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, I’ve kept you standing in order to show you my power and to declare my name in all the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are still acting arrogantly against my people by not letting them go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look! About this time tomorrow, I’ll send a severe hail storm, such as has not happened in Egypt from the day it was founded until now.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So send for your livestock and everything that belongs to you that’s out in the field, because every person and animal found in the field that has not been brought inside to shelters will die when the hail comes down on them.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whoever feared the message from the Lord among Pharaoh’s officials made his servants and livestock flee into shelters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But whoever did not pay attention to the message from the Lord left his servants and his livestock outside in the fields.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord told Moses, “Stretch out your hand toward heaven, and there will be hail in all the land of Egypt, on people, animals, and all the vegetation of the field throughout the land of Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Moses stretched out his staff toward heaven, the Lord sent thunder and hail, and lightning struck the earth. The Lord rained hail on the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was very heavy hail, and lightning was flashing continuously in the midst of the hail. There had not been anything like it in the land of Egypt since it had become a nation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The hail struck everything, including people and animals, outside in the fields throughout the land of Egypt. The hail struck all the vegetation of the fields and shattered all the trees in the orchards.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Only in the land of Goshen, where the Israelis were, was there no hail.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh sent word and called for Moses and Aaron. “I’ve sinned this time,” he told them. “The Lord is righteous, but I and my people are wicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pray to the Lord! There has been enough of God’s thunder and hail! I’ll let you go, and you need not stay any longer.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses told him, “When I leave the city I’ll spread out my hands to the Lord. The thunder will cease and the hail won’t continue, so that you may know that the earth belongs to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But as for you and your officials, I know that you don’t yet fear the Lord God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Now the flax and the barley were ruined because the barley was in ear and the flax was in bud.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The wheat and the wild grain were not ruined because they were late crops.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses went out of the city from Pharaoh and spread out his hands to the Lord. The thunder and hail stopped, and the rain no longer poured out on the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Pharaoh saw that the rain, hail, and thunder had stopped, he continued to sin. He, along with his officials, hardened his heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh’s heart was stubborn, and he did not let the Israelis go, just as the Lord had said through Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord told Moses, “Go to Pharaoh, for I’ve hardened his heart and the hearts of his officials in order to perform these signs of mine among them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so you may tell your children and your grandchildren how I toyed with the Egyptians and about my miraculous signs that I performed among them, so all of you may know that I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh and told him, “This is what the Lord God of the Hebrews says: ‘How long will you refuse to humble yourself before me? Let my people go, so they may serve me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you refuse to let my people go, tomorrow I’m going to bring locusts into your territory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They’ll cover the surface of the land so a person cannot see the ground, and they’ll eat what is left for you of the residue from the hail. They’ll also eat all your trees that grow in the orchards.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your houses will be filled, along with the houses of all your officials and the houses of all the Egyptians—something that neither your fathers nor your ancestors ever saw from the time they were on earth until now.’” Then Moses turned and left Pharaoh’s presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the officials of Pharaoh told him, “How long will this man be a snare to us? Let the people go so they may serve the Lord their God! Don’t you realize yet that Egypt is about to be destroyed?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses and Aaron were brought back to Pharaoh and he told them, “Go, serve the Lord your God. But exactly who will go?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said, “We will go with our young and with our old. We will go with our sons and our daughters, with our sheep and our cattle, because it’s a festival to the Lord for us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh told them, “The Lord will certainly be with you if I let you and your little ones go. I know some evil plan is in your mind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No! Let the men go and serve the Lord, for that is what you were seeking.” Then they were driven out from the presence of Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord told Moses, “Stretch out your hand over the land of Egypt to bring the locusts, and they’ll come up over the land of Egypt and eat all the vegetation of the land, everything that the hail left.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses stretched out his staff over the land of Egypt, and the Lord sent an east wind into the land all that day and throughout the night. When morning came, the east wind brought the locusts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The locusts came up over all the land of Egypt and settled on all the territory of Egypt in great swarms. There had never been locusts like this before nor would there ever be again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They covered the surface of the entire land so that it was dark. They ate all the vegetation of the land and the fruit from the trees that the hail left. Nothing green was left on the trees or on the vegetation in all the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh quickly called Moses and Aaron and said, “I’ve sinned against the Lord your God and against you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, please forgive my sin only this time, and pray to the Lord your God that he would at least remove this from me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses left Pharaoh and prayed to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord brought a very strong west wind that took the locusts and drove them into the Reed Sea. Not one locust remained in all the territory of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord made Pharaoh’s heart stubborn and he would not let the Israelis go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord told Moses, “Stretch your hand toward the sky and there will be darkness over the land of Egypt, a darkness that one can feel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses stretched his hand toward the sky, and there was thick darkness in all the land of Egypt for three days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No one could see anyone else, nor could anyone get up from his place for three days. But there was light for all the Israelis in their dwellings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh called Moses and said, “Go serve the Lord, but your flocks and your cattle are to remain. Even your little ones can go with you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said, “You must let us have sacrifices and burnt offerings to offer to the Lord our God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And even our livestock must go with us. Not a hoof will be left behind because we will use some of them to serve the Lord our God, and until we get there we won’t know what we need to serve the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord made Pharaoh’s heart stubborn, and he did not want to let them go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh told him, “Get away from me! Watch out that you never see my face again, because on the day you see my face, you will die!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said, “Just as you have said, I won’t see your face again!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord told Moses, “I’ll bring one more plague on Pharaoh and Egypt. After that he’ll let you leave from here, and when he lets you go, he will certainly drive you out from here.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tell the people that each man is to ask his neighbor and each woman her neighbor for articles of silver and gold.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord made the Egyptians look on the people with favor. Also the man Moses was highly regarded in the land of Egypt, both in the opinion of Pharaoh’s officials and in the opinion of the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses announced to Pharaoh, “This is what the Lord says: ‘About midnight I’m going throughout Egypt,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and all the firstborn in the land of Egypt will die, from the firstborn of Pharaoh who sits on his throne to the firstborn of the slave girl who operates the hand mill, along with the firstborn of the animals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There will be a great cry throughout the land of Egypt, like there has never been and never will be again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But among the Israelis, from people to animals, not even a dog will bark, so you may know that the Lord is distinguishing between the Egyptians and the Israelis.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All these officials of yours will come down to me, prostrate themselves to me, and say, ‘Get out, you and all the people following you!’ After that I’ll go out.” Then Moses angrily left Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord told Moses, “Pharaoh won’t listen to you. As a result, my wonders will increase throughout the land of Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses and Aaron did all these wonders in front of Pharaoh, but the Lord made Pharaoh’s heart stubborn, and he would not let the Israelis go out from his land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord told Moses and Aaron in the land of Egypt,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This month will mark the beginning of months for you. It will be the first month of the year for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tell the entire congregation of Israel, ‘On the tenth of this month they’re each to take a lamb for themselves, according to their ancestors’ households, one lamb for each household.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If a household is too small for a lamb, then it and its closest neighbor are to obtain one based on the number of individuals—dividing the lamb based on what each person can eat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your lamb is to be a year old male without blemish. You may take it from the sheep or from the goats.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is to remain under your care until the fourteenth day of this month, and then the entire assembly of the congregation of Israel is to slaughter it at twilight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They’re to take some of the blood and put it on the two doorposts and on the lintel of the houses where they eat the lamb.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That very night they’re to eat the meat, roasted over the fire, with unleavened bread and bitter herbs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t eat any of it raw or boiled in water. Instead, roast it over the fire, with its head, legs, and internal organs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t leave any of it until morning, and whatever does remain of it until morning you are to burn in the fire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “‘This is how you are to eat it: with your cloak tucked into your belt, your sandals on your feet, and your staff in your hand. You are to eat it hurriedly—it’s the Lord’s Passover.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll pass through the land of Egypt that night and strike every firstborn in the land of Egypt, both people and animals. I’ll execute judgments on all the gods of Egypt. I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The blood will be a sign for you on the houses where you are. I’ll see the blood and pass over you. There will be no plague to destroy you when I strike the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “‘This day is to be a memorial for you, and you are to celebrate it as a festival to the Lord. You are to celebrate it as a perpetual ordinance from generation to generation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are to eat unleavened bread for seven days. On the first day be sure to remove all the leaven from your houses, because any person who eats anything leavened from the first day until the seventh will be cut off from Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also, on the first day you’re to hold a holy assembly, and on the seventh day you’re to hold a holy assembly. No work is to be done during those days, except for preparing what is to be eaten by each person.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “‘You are to observe the Festival of Unleavened Bread, since on this very day I brought your tribal divisions from the land of Egypt. You are to observe this day from generation to generation as a perpetual ordinance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the first month, from the evening of the fourteenth day of the month until the evening of the twenty-first day of the month, you are to eat unleavened bread.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For seven days leaven is not to be found in your houses. Indeed, any person who eats anything leavened, is to be cut off from the congregation of Israel, whether an alien or a native of the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are not to eat what is leavened. You are to eat unleavened bread in all your settlements.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses summoned all the elders of Israel and told them, “Choose sheep for your families, and slaughter the Passover lamb.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take a bundle of hyssop and dip it in the blood that is in the basin, and apply some of the blood in the basin to the lintel and the two doorposts. None of you is to go out of the doorway of his house until morning,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because the Lord will pass through to strike down the Egyptians, and when he sees the blood on the lintel and the two doorposts, the Lord will pass over the doorway, and won’t allow the destroyer to enter your houses to strike you down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are to observe this event as a perpetual ordinance for you and your children forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you enter the land that the Lord will give you, just as he promised, you are to observe this ritual.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when your children say to you, ‘What does this ritual mean?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: you are to say, ‘It is the Passover sacrifice to the Lord, who passed over the houses of the Israelis in Egypt when he struck down the Egyptians but spared our houses.’” Then the people bowed down and worshipped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelis did this. Moses and Aaron did just what the Lord had commanded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And so at midnight the Lord struck down every firstborn in the land of Egypt, from the firstborn of Pharaoh who sat on his throne to the firstborn of the prisoner who was in the dungeon, and all the firstborn of the livestock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh got up during the night, he, all his officials, and all the Egyptians, and there was loud wailing in Egypt, because there was not a house without someone dead in it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he summoned Moses and Aaron during the night and told them: “Get up, go out from among my people, both you and the Israelis! Go, serve the Lord as you have said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take both your sheep and your cattle, just as you demanded and go! And bless me too!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Egyptian officials urged the people to send them out of the land quickly, because they were saying, “We’ll all be dead!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the people took their dough before it was leavened, with their kneading bowls wrapped up in their cloaks on their shoulders.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, the Israelis had done as Moses said; they had asked the Egyptians for objects of silver and objects of gold, and for clothes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord had given the people favor in the eyes of the Egyptians, so that they gave them what they requested. As a result, they plundered the Egyptians.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: About 600,000 Israeli men traveled from Rameses to Succoth on foot, not counting children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A mixed multitude also went up with them, along with a very large number of livestock, including sheep and cattle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They baked the dough that they brought out of Egypt into thin cakes of unleavened bread. It had not been leavened because they were driven out of Egypt and could not wait, nor had they prepared provisions for themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the time that the Israelis lived in Egypt was 430 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the end of 430 years, to the very day, all the tribal divisions of the Lord went out from the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That was for the Lord a night of vigil to bring them out of the land of Egypt. This same night belongs to the Lord, and is to be a vigil for all the Israelis from generation to generation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord told Moses and Aaron, “These are the regulations for the Passover: No foreigner is to eat it,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: though any slave purchased with money may eat it after you have circumcised him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But no temporary resident or a hired servant is to eat it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is to be eaten in one house, and you are not to take any of the meat outside the house, nor are you to break any of its bones.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole congregation of Israel is to observe it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If an alien who resides with you wants to observe the Passover to the Lord, every male in his household must be circumcised, and then he may come near to observe it. He is to be like a native of the land, but no uncircumcised person is to eat it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A single law exists for the native and the alien who resides among you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the Israelis did this. They did exactly as the Lord commanded Moses and Aaron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And on that very day, the Lord brought the Israelis out of the land of Egypt by their tribal divisions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord spoke to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Consecrate to me every firstborn male. Whatever is the first to open the womb among the Israelis, both of humans and of animals, belongs to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses told the people, “Remember this day on which you came out of Egypt, from the house of bondage, because the Lord brought you out from this place with a strong show of force. Moreover, nothing leavened is to be eaten.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Today, in the month of Abib, you are going out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Lord brings you to the land of the Canaanite, the Hittite, the Amorite, the Hivite, and the Jebusite, which he swore to your ancestors to give you—a land flowing with milk and honey—you are to observe this ritual in this month.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are to eat unleavened bread for seven days, and on the seventh day there is to be a festival to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Unleavened bread is to be eaten for seven days, and nothing leavened is to be seen among you, nor is leaven to be seen among you throughout your territory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And you are to tell your child on that day, ‘This is because of what the Lord did for me when I came out of Egypt.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is to be a sign for you on your hand and a reminder on your forehead, so that you may speak about the instruction of the Lord; for the Lord brought you out of Egypt with a strong show of force.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are to keep this ordinance at its appointed time from year to year.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When the Lord brings you to the land of the Canaanite and gives it to you, just as he promised you and your ancestors,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: you are to dedicate to the Lord everything that first opens the womb. All the firstborn males of your livestock belong to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are to redeem every firstborn donkey with a lamb, and if you don’t redeem it, you are to break its neck. You are to redeem every firstborn among your sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then when your child asks you in the future, ‘What is this?’, you are to say to him, ‘The Lord brought us out of Egypt, from the house of bondage with a strong show of force.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when Pharaoh stubbornly refused to let us go, the Lord killed every firstborn in the land of Egypt, from the firstborn of humans to the firstborn of animals. Therefore, I sacrifice to the Lord every male that first opens the womb, but I redeem every firstborn of my sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is to be a sign on your hand and an emblem on your forehead, because the Lord brought us out of Egypt with a strong show of force.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Pharaoh let the people go, God did not lead them along the road through the land of the Philistines, even though it was nearer, because God had said, “If the people face war, they may change their minds and return to Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So God led the people the roundabout way of the desert toward the Reed Sea. The Israelis went up from the land of Egypt in military formation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses took the bones of Joseph with him, because Joseph had made the Israelis take this solemn oath: “God will certainly take notice of you, and then you must carry my bones up with you from here.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They left Succoth and camped in Etham at the edge of the desert.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord went in front of them by day in a pillar of cloud to lead them along the way, and by night in a pillar of fire to give them light, so they could travel both day and night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Neither the pillar of cloud by day nor the pillar of fire by night left its place in front of the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord told Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Tell the Israelis that they are to turn back and camp in front of Pi-hahiroth, between Migdol and the sea. You are to camp in front of Baal-zephon, opposite it by the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh will say about the Israelis, ‘They’re wandering aimlessly in the land, and the desert has closed in on them.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ve made Pharaoh’s heart stubborn so he will pursue them. But I’ll receive honor by means of Pharaoh and his army, so that the Egyptians will know that I am the Lord.” So this is what the Israelis did.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the king of Egypt was told that the people had fled, the minds of Pharaoh and his officials changed toward the people, and they said, “What have we done in releasing Israel from serving us?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Pharaoh had his chariot prepared and took his troops with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took 600 of the best chariots, and all the other chariots of Egypt with officers in charge of each one.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord made the heart of Pharaoh, king of Egypt, stubborn, and he defiantly pursued the Israelis as they were leaving.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Egyptians pursued them—all the chariot-horses of Pharaoh, along with his horsemen and army—and they overtook them camped by the sea, near Pi-hahiroth, in front of Baal Zephon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As Pharaoh approached, the Israelis looked up, and there were the Egyptians bearing down on them! Extremely frightened, the Israelis cried out to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They also told Moses, “Was it because there were no graves in Egypt that you took us out to die in the desert? What have you done to us, by bringing us out of Egypt?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Is this not what we told you in Egypt, when we said, ‘Leave us alone!’ and ‘Let us serve the Egyptians!’? Indeed, it would have been better for us to serve the Egyptians than to die in the desert!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses told the people, “Don’t be afraid! Stand still and watch how the Lord will deliver you today, because you will never again see the Egyptians whom you’re looking at today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord will fight for you while you keep still.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord told Moses, “Why are you crying out to me? Tell the Israelis to move out!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are to raise your staff, stretch out your hand over the sea, and divide it, so the Israelis may go into the middle of the sea on dry land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even now I’m hardening the heart of the Egyptians so they’ll go after the Israelis. Then I’ll receive honor by means of Pharaoh and all his army, his chariots, and his horsemen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Egyptians will know that I am the Lord when I receive honor by means of Pharaoh, his chariots, and his horsemen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the angel of God, who was going in front of the camp of Israel, moved behind them. The pillar of cloud also moved from in front of them and stood behind them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: coming between the camp of the Egyptians and the camp of Israel. The cloud remained there even in the darkness, illuminating the night, so that the one side did not come near the other all night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses stretched out his hand over the sea, and the Lord caused the water to retreat by a strong east wind all night, turning the sea into dry land. As the waters were divided,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the Israelis went into the middle of the sea on dry land, and the waters formed a wall for them on their right and on their left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Egyptians pursued—all the horses of Pharaoh, his chariots, and his horsemen—and they went into the middle of the sea after them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the morning watch, the Lord looked down on the Egyptian camp through the pillar of fire and cloud, and he threw the Egyptian camp into confusion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made the wheels of their chariots wobble so that they drove them with difficulty. The Egyptians said, “Let’s flee from Israel because the Lord is fighting for them and against us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord told Moses, “Stretch out your hand over the sea and the water will come back over the Egyptians, over their chariots, and over their horsemen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses stretched out his hand over the sea, and the water returned to its normal depth at daybreak. The Egyptians tried to retreat in front of the advancing water, but the Lord destroyed the Egyptians in the middle of the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The water returned, covering the chariots and the horsemen of Pharaoh’s entire army that had pursued the Israelis into the sea. Not a single one of them remained.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Israelis walked through the middle of the sea on dry land, and the water stood like a wall for them on their right and on their left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On that day the Lord delivered Israel from the hand of the Egyptians, and Israel saw the Egyptians dead along the seashore.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Israel saw the great force by which the Lord had acted against the Egyptians, the people feared the Lord, and they believed the Lord and Moses his servant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Moses and the Israelis sang this song to the Lord:
“I’ll sing to the Lord,
    for he is highly exalted.
The horse and its rider
    he has thrown into the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord is my strength and song,
    and he has become my salvation.
This is my God and I’ll praise him,
    the God of my father and I’ll exalt him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord is a man of war,
    the Lord is his name!
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
The deep covered them,
    they went down into the depths like a rock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your right hand, Lord, was majestic in strength,
    your right hand, Lord, shattered the enemy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In the greatness of your majesty
    you broke down your enemies.
You sent forth your anger,
    it consumed them like stubble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
By the breath of your nostrils
    the waters were piled up,
the flowing waters stood up like a hill,
    the deep waters congealed in the heart of the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The enemy said, ‘I’ll pursue them, I’ll overtake them,
    I’ll divide the spoil.
I’ll satisfy my anger on them,
    I’ll draw my sword,
        and my hand will bring them to ruin.’
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
“Who is like you among the gods, Lord?
    Who is like you, majestic in holiness,
        awesome in splendor, and working wonders?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You stretched out your right hand,
    and the earth swallowed them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“You have led with your gracious love
    this people whom you redeemed.
You have guided them with your strength
    to your holy dwelling.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The nations heard and they quaked,
    anguish seized the inhabitants of Philistia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the chiefs of Edom were terrified,
    the nobles of Moab trembled uncontrollably,
        and all the inhabitants of Canaan melted away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Dread and fear have fallen on them,
    because of the strength of your arm.
They have become silent as a stone,
    until your people pass by, Lord,
        until this people you acquired pass by.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“You will bring them in and plant them
    on the mountain of your inheritance.
You have made a place where you will reside, Lord.
    Your own hands have established a sanctuary, Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord will reign forever and ever.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the horses of Pharaoh, his chariots, and his horsemen went into the sea, the Lord caused the waters of the sea to come back over them, but the Israelis walked through the middle of the sea on dry land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Miriam the prophetess, Aaron’s sister, took a tambourine in her hand and went out with all the women behind her with tambourines and dancing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Miriam sang to them,
“Sing to the Lord, for he is highly exalted!
    The horse and its rider
        he has thrown into the sea.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses led Israel from the Reed Sea and they went to the desert of Shur. They traveled into the desert for three days and did not find water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they came to Marah, they could not drink the water at Marah because it was bitter. (That is why it’s called Marah.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the people complained against Moses: “What are we to drink?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Moses cried out to the Lord, and the Lord showed him a tree, which he threw into the water, and the water became sweet.
There the Lord presented to them a statute and an ordinance, and there he tested them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “If you will carefully obey the Lord your God, do what he sees to be right, listen to his commandments, and keep all his statutes, then I won’t inflict on you all the diseases that I inflicted on the Egyptians, because I am the Lord your healer.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they came to Elim where there were twelve springs of water and 70 palm trees, and they camped there by the water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later, they left Elim, and the whole congregation of the Israelis came to the desert of Sin, which lay between Elim and Sinai, on the fifteenth day of the second month after their departure from the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole congregation of the Israelis complained against Moses and Aaron in the desert.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelis told them, “If only we had died by the Lord’s hand in the land of Egypt when we sat by the cooking pots, when we ate bread until we were filled—because you brought us to this desert to kill this entire congregation with hunger.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord told Moses, “Listen very carefully! I’ll cause food to rain down for you from heaven, and the people are to go out and gather each day’s portion on that day. In this way I’ll test them to demonstrate whether or not they’ll live according to my instructions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the sixth day, when they prepare what they bring in, it will be double what they gather on other days.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses and Aaron addressed the entire congregation of the Israelis: “This evening you will know that the Lord has brought you out of the land of Egypt,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and in the morning you will see the glory of the Lord, because he has heard your complaints against him. After all, who are we that you complain against us?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses also said, “When the Lord gives you meat to eat in the evening, and bread in the morning to satisfy you, the Lord will hear your complaints directed against him. Who are we? Your complaints aren’t against us, but rather against the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses instructed Aaron, “Say to the whole congregation of the Israelis, ‘Come near into the Lord’s presence, because he has heard your complaints.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Aaron was speaking to all the congregation of the Israelis, they turned toward the desert, and there the glory of the Lord was seen in the cloud.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord told Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I’ve heard the complaints of the Israelis. Tell them, ‘At twilight you are to eat meat and in the morning you are to be filled with bread, so you may know that I am the Lord your God.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later that evening quail came up and covered the camp, and then in the morning there was a layer of dew around the camp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the layer of dew evaporated, on the surface of the desert a fine flaky substance, as fine as frost, appeared on the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the Israelis saw it, they asked one another, “What is it?”, because they did not know what it was.
Moses told them, “It’s the food that the Lord has given you to eat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord has commanded: ‘You are to gather from it what each person is to eat, about one omer per person according to the number of your people, and one person is to gather for everyone in his tent.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelis did this, some gathering much, some little.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they measured it with a vessel the capacity of which was one omer, the one who gathered much did not have an excess, while the one who gathered little did not lack. They gathered exactly what each needed to eat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses told them, “No one is to leave any of it until morning.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But they did not listen to Moses—some people left part of it until morning, and it produced maggots and smelled bad, so Moses got angry at them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Every morning they gathered it, according to what each needed to eat; and when the sun became hot, it melted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the sixth day they gathered twice as much bread, about two omers per person. Then all the leaders of the congregation came and reported to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and he told them, “This is what the Lord said: ‘Tomorrow is a Sabbath observance, a holy Sabbath to the Lord. Bake what you want to bake and boil what you want to boil, and put aside whatever remains to be kept for yourselves until morning.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they put it away until morning, as Moses commanded, and it did not smell bad, and there were no maggots in it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said, “Eat it today, since today is a Sabbath to the Lord, and today you won’t find it in the field.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For six days you are to gather it, but on the seventh day, the Sabbath, there won’t be any.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, that seventh day some of the people went out to gather, but they did not find any.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord asked Moses, “How long will you people refuse to keep my commandments and my instructions?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You see that the Lord has given you the Sabbath, and so on the sixth day he gives you food for two days. Let each person stay where he is; let no one leave his place on the seventh day.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the people rested on the seventh day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelis named it “manna”. It was white like coriander seed, and tasted like a wafer made with honey.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said, “This is what the Lord has commanded: ‘Set aside one omer of it for future generations, so that they may see the food with which I fed you in the desert when I brought you out of the land of Egypt.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses told Aaron, “Take a jar, fill it with about one omer of manna, and place it in the Lord’s presence, to be preserved throughout future generations.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Aaron placed it before the Testimony to be kept, just as the Lord had commanded Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelis ate manna for 40 years until they came to a land where they could settle. They ate manna until they came to the border of the land of Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now one omer is a tenth of an ephah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole congregation of the Israelis set out from the desert of Sin, traveling from place to place according to the command of the Lord. They camped at Rephidim, but there was no water for the people to drink.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The people quarreled with Moses: “Give us water to drink.”
Moses told them, “Why are you quarreling with me? Why are you testing the Lord?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the people were thirsty there for water, so they complained against Moses: “Why did you bring us up from Egypt to kill us, our children, and our livestock with thirst?”
verses.speaker: Narrator
